p: The hot plate test was employed to assess antinociceptive activity. In the hot plate test, the response to pain stimuli is relayed to the supraspinal reflex mediated by μ 1 and μ 2 opioid receptors [ 30]. This test was developed by Woolfe & Macdonald in 1944 [ 31] and improved by many other researchers, such as Eddy et al. [ 32] and O'Callaghan and Holtzman [ 33]. In all of these cases, antinociceptive activity is characterized by an increased tolerance to pain by the animal when in contact with a heated plate.
